title: all-medium.md
text:
They *intended* to write. They really did.

But more fluently came *how* to write, *how* to display, *how* to convey.

Before there was a **what** there were [empty](./empty.json) [vehicles](./empty.yaml)
[crewed by a token](./be.txt):

* [dusty](./story-in-a-story.mjs)
* [unused](./log.mjs)
* [unfinished](./funsole.mjs)
* [ill-defined](./cat-detector.psu)

be.canvas.html
text:
<canvas id="belgium" width="100vw" height="100vh"> </canvas>

<script>
  belgium.width = screen.width;
  belgium.height = screen.height;

  const regions = screen.width / 3;

  const be = belgium.getContext('2d');
  be.fillStyle = 'black';
  be.fillRect(0, 0, regions, screen.height);
  be.fillStyle = 'yellow';
  be.fillRect(regions, 0, regions, screen.height);
  be.fillStyle = 'red';
  be.fillRect(regions + regions, 0, regions, screen.height);
</script>

bunny.md
text:
# 🐰

> If drawing rabbits (🐇) in JavaScript means copying
> [patterns out of books](./the-fun-parts.md) or mimicking specific styles from blogs,
> drawing bunnies (🐰) is about experimentation and creative expression
>
> To draw a 🐰 is to pervert the conventions of the language. To draw your breath or to
> get it all out as fast as possible. It’s an exercise in discovering and pushing the
> bounds of your understanding of the language. It’s about reinforcing and challenging
> JavaScript as a craft.
>
> In drawing JavaScript 🐰s, you’re always at play. And you’re getting better.
>
> * [Jacob Thornton](https://github.com/fat) from
>   [*How to draw a Bunny*](https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/beautiful-javascript/9781449371142/ch03.html)

title: cat-detector.js.md
text:
# Cat Detector

On the surface, a cat detector is a just simple program:

* First it asks you for a cat:
  ```js
  let input = prompt('cat, please');
  ```
* Then it checks if you gave it a cat:
  ```js
  const isCat = input === 'cat';
  ```
* If did give it a cat, the detector is satisfied:
  ```js
  if (isCat) alert('thank you for the cat');
  ```
* Otherwise it keeps asking you for a cat until you give it one:
  ```js
  else {
  	while (input !== 'cat') input = prompt('still not a cat. \n\ncat, please');
  ```
* When you're done out-stubborning a computer, the program ends:
  ```js
  	alert('finally, a cat.');
  }
  ```

But really, a cat detector is an excuse to [draw a bunny](./bunny.md).

title: cat-detector.psu
text:
maybe <- null

WHILE maybe IS NOT "cat"

  DISPLAY helpful feedback
END WHILE

DISPLAY "thank you for the cat"

title: cat-detector.scm.js
cat-detector.scm.json
text:
[
  ["define", ["get a cat", "message"],
    [["define", "maybe", ["*log", "prompt", "message"]],
    ["cond",
      [["=", "maybe", null],
        [["alert", "there is no escape"], ["get a cat", "message"]]],
      [["not", ["=", "maybe", "cat"]],
        [["alert", ["+", "'", "maybe", "' is not cat"]], ["get a cat", "message"]]],
      ["else", ["maybe"]]]]],

  ["get a cat", "'cat' please"],

  ["alert", "thank you for the cat"]
]

    <tspan x="10" dy="2em"><tspan class="keyword">alert</tspan>(<tspan class="string">'thank you for the cat'</tspan>);

title: deep-clone.mjs
deep-compare.mjs
text:
export const deepCompare = (actual, expected) =>
  actual === expected ||
  Object.is(actual, expected) ||
  (Object(actual) === actual &&
    Object(expected) === expected &&
    ((Array.isArray(actual) &&
      Array.isArray(expected) &&
      actual.length === expected.length &&
      expected.every((expected, index) => deepCompare(actual[index], expected))) ||
      (Object.keys(actual).length === Object.keys(expected).length &&
        Object.keys(expected).every((key) => deepCompare(actual[key], expected[key])))));

export default deepCompare;

// tags: useful, testing

dweet.md
text:
# Dweet

> Dweeting is a challenge to see what awesomeness you can create when limited to only 140
> characters of javascript and a canvas. Give it a go!
>
> * [dwitter.net](https://www.dwitter.net/)

Dweets are wrapped in a function named `u` that's called 60 times per second:

```js
function u(t) {
  // 140 characters or less
}
```

You can use these variables:

* `t`: elapsed time in seconds.
* `c`: A 1920x1080 canvas.
* `x`: A 2D context for that canvas.
* `S`: Math.sin
* `C`: Math.cos
* `T`: Math.tan
* `R`: Generates rgba-strings, ex.: R(255, 255, 255, 0.5)

interval-training.html
text:
<script type="module">
  import noises from './noises.mjs';

  alert(
    'use the mouse and arrow keys to change two tones\n\n' +
      'click the screen to begin',
  );

  document.body.addEventListener('click', function initNoises() {
    const { frequency: mouseFreq, volume: mouseVol } = noises().play();
    const mouseTone = (e) => {
      mouseVol(1 / (e.screenY / screen.height));
      mouseFreq((e.screenX / screen.width) * 880);
    };
    document.body.addEventListener('mousemove', mouseTone);

    const keyState = { freq: 440, vol: 1 };
    const { frequency: keyFreq, volume: keyVol } = noises().play();
    const arrowsTone = (e) => {
      if (e.key === 'ArrowUp') keyVol((keyState.vol += 0.05));
      else if (e.key === 'ArrowDown') keyVol((keyState.vol -= 0.05));
      else if (e.key === 'ArrowRight') keyFreq((keyState.freq += 1));
      else if (e.key === 'ArrowLeft') keyFreq((keyState.freq -= 1));
    };
    document.body.addEventListener('keydown', arrowsTone);

    document.body.removeEventListener('click', initNoises);
  });
</script>

title: sierpinski.html
text:
<link rel="stylesheet" href="./center.css" />

<canvas id="t-pad" height="1000" width="1000"></canvas>

<script type="module">
  import turtlje from './turtlje.mjs';
  const { left, right, forward, goto } = turtlje('t-pad');

  goto(150, 0);
  halfSierpinski(3, 5);
  right(90).forward(3).right(90);
  halfSierpinski(3, 5);

  function halfSierpinski(size, level) {
    if (level <= 0) {
      forward(size);
    } else {
      part(size, level);
      right(90).forward(size).right(90);
      part(size, level);
    }
  }

  function part(size, level) {
    halfSierpinski(size, level - 1);
    left(45)
      .forward(size * Math.SQRT2)
      .left(45);
    halfSierpinski(size, level - 1);
  }
</script>

<!-- tags: sketch -->
<!-- credit: https://github.com/bjpop/js-turtle/blob/master/examples/sierpinski.js -->

const stack = (fn) => (names) =>
  names.length === 0
    ? fn
    : stack
      ({ [names[0]]: (...args) => fn(...args) }[names[0]]) 
      (names.slice(1));

stack
  (function busted() { yolo; })
  (['too', 'bad', 'so', 'sad'])
  ();

the-fun-parts.md
text:
# JavaScript: The ~~Good~~ *Fun* Parts

> Most programming languages contain ~~good~~ *fun* parts and ~~bad~~ *boring* parts. I
> discovered that I could be a better programmer by using only the ~~good~~ *fun* parts
> and avoiding the ~~bad~~ *boring* parts. After all, how can you build something ~~good~~
> *fun* out of ~~bad~~ *boring* parts? \[...] But you have the power to define your own
> subset. You can write better programs by relying exclusively on the ~~good~~ *fun*
> parts.
>
> * adapted by **Dougie Crockpot** from
>   [the original](https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/javascript-the-good/9780596517748/)
alt: JavaScripting: teach me how to, Dougie.

title: useless-machine.2.html
text:
<script>
  class UselessMachine extends HTMLInputElement {
    constructor() {
      super();
      this.type = 'checkbox';
      this.addEventListener('click', () => {
        setTimeout(() => (this.checked = false), 500);
      });
    }
  }

  customElements.define('useless-machine', UselessMachine, { extends: 'input' });
</script>

<input is="useless-machine" />

reverse-input.txt.js.st.txt
text:
Get some text from the user.

  Then create a new empty text.

  Now start at the beginning of the user input,
     One by one, copy each character to the beginning of the new text.

  Finally, show the new text to the user.
